page.title: 15NAMES GREENHALGH/ROSEACRE
page.content: Greenhalgh is recorded in the Domesday Book and has a variety of spellings, Grenefolf being the earliest noted. Roseacre is recorded on Saxton's map of 1577. The name is Saxon, Ros - a wood, and Ach - abounding in. Thistleton, from Twistle meaning a boundary, appears in 1611 on Speed's map of Lancashire. Elswick Leys on the outskirts of Elswick, is reputed to be the site of the earliest of the three Methodists churches. No remains have been found. Esprick, whose ancient form, Estbrick, and Medlar, ancient form Midelargh, are less easy to pinpoint. Scholar Brook takes its name from Skali, meaning a hut, and is the boundary between Roseacre and Medlar.
